article.headline: âThe stakes are really highâ for Pence in VP debate as Trump campaign seeks to narrow Biden lead in polls, experts say
article.body: Wednesday nightâs vice presidential debate could be a turning point in President Donald Trumpâs quest for reelection, with less than a month remaining in the campaign and polls showing him trailing former Vice President Joe Biden by a significant margin, experts say. Bidenâs average lead in national polls increased from 7.1% to 8.1% after some viewers were turned off by the presidentâs combative style during last weekâs debate, according to Five Thirty Eight, and experts say that Vice President Mike Pence must put in a strong performance against the Democratic nominee, Sen. Kamala Harris of California, to turn the electorateâs attention away from the first presidential debate and a barrage of negative news coverage related to Trumpâs recent COVID-19 diagnosis and subsequent hospitalization. The vice-presidential debate will take place in Salt Lake City on Wednesday at 9 p.m. Eastern Time, and will run until 10:30 p.m., without commercial breaks. âTrump didnât have a great first debate in 2016, and Pence was able to follow that up with a strong debate performance,â said Steve Pavlick, head of policy at Renaissance Macro Research and former deputy assistant secretary for legislative affairs at the Treasury Department under Trump, pointing to a CNN poll that showed viewers believed Pence won the debate. âIf Trump is going to make a comeback, Pence has to have a really good debate to get some momentum going,â he added. âThat happened in 2016, so itâs not unprecedented, but the stakes are really high.â While the presidentâs supporters are eager to point out that polls four years ago predicted that it was unlikely that Trump would win the 2016 election, the data shows the president in an even weaker position this time around. RealClearPoliticsâ polling average projects Biden will garner 51.3% of the national popular vote, compared to Trumpâs 42.1%, a 9.3% gap, versus a 46.8% to 43.6% lead, or 3.2% on Oct. 6, 2016. Polls at that time showed Trump projected to win the battleground states of Florida, Ohio, North Carolina and Nevada, whereas, on average, polls today show Biden ahead in all four. Joel Goldstein, professor emeritus at Saint Louis University School of Law and scholar of the vice presidency, told MarketWatch that one factor that may blunt the impact of Wednesdayâs event is that vice presidential debates tend to garner less attention than presidential ones. At the same time, there are factors that could draw the publicâs attention and provide the trailing Trump campaign with the opportunity to burnish its reputation with voters. âBecause of Trumpâs recent COVID diagnosis and because of the advanced ages of the candidates, itâs possible that the vice presidential debate could take on a larger importance in terms of peopleâs attention,â due to the increased chance that age and illness could lead to either candidateâs incapacitation and their respective vice presidents assuming the powers of the presidency, Goldstein said. Meanwhile, the historic nature of Harrisâs vice presidential candidacy could be another factor garnering increased attention. According to Nielsen Media Research data cited by the Commission on Presidential Debates, the two highest-rated vice presidential debates in history were in 1984 and 2008, when Geraldine Ferraro and Sarah Palin were the first and second female major-party vice presidential candidates in history. This year, âItâs the first time that a woman is running on a ticket that had a good chance of winning,â Goldstein said, pointing out that Walter Mondale and John McCain were significant underdogs at the time they chose a female running mate. âThe selection in each case was a hail mary, and this time, Biden is favored.â Trumpâs recent COVID-19 diagnosis will alter the nature of the debate, as the candidates will now sit at least 12 feet apart rather than the originally planned seven feet, according to Politico, while the Washington Post reported late Tuesday that both campaigns had agreed to the erection of plexiglass barriers between the candidates as further protection, after the Trump campaign had earlier resisted the move. While Pence has not tested positive for COVID-19, he was present a Rose Garden ceremony on Sept. 26 that was attended by several top Republicans who have since tested positive, including President Trump, former White House adviser Kellyanne Conway, former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, Utah Sen. Mike Lee, North Carolina Sen. Thom Tillis and Wisconsin Sen. Ron Johnson. The Commission on Presidential Debates did not respond to multiple requests for comment on its comprehensive protocol for preventing the spread of the virus at the debate. Recent events will likely place the novel coronavirus front and center as an issue during the debate, according to Renaissance Macroâs Pavlick. He argued that with Trump back in the White House, Pence will look to paint the presidentâs experience as a success, due to rapid testing and recently developed treatments for the disease. âHeâll argue that you shouldnât be afraid, you shouldnât have the same level of fear as back in March and that Democrats are fear mongering,â he said. âThatâs the message they have to paint and do this jujutsu on the coronavirus that turns the issue from a weakness to a strength.â The president began pushing such a message in prerecorded videos disseminated on social media, claiming that he had already recovered from the disease and telling Americans, âdonât be afraid of COVID, donât let it dominate your life,â even though his doctor cautioned Monday that âhe may not be out of the woods yet.â
